dialogue_content.speaker: Interviewer
dialogue_content.text: I'd love to hear about your experiences driving in New York City during the 1980s.

dialogue_content.original_text: Oh, the 80s! That was quite a time to be driving a taxi in NYC, let me tell you.
dialogue_content.speaker: Subject

dialogue_content.original_text: There were no GPS devices like today, so you really had to know your way around.
dialogue_content.speaker: Subject

dialogue_content.original_text: I used to keep a map in the car just in case.
dialogue_content.speaker: Subject
Interviewer
dialogue_content.text: It sounds like the 1980s were quite a vibrant time in the city. What was it like navigating without modern technology?

dialogue_content.original_text: Like, 'Turn right at the deli with the big red sign,' or 'Take a left by the park with the old oak tree.'
dialogue_content.speaker: Subject
Interviewer
dialogue_content.text: That sounds like a unique experience, driving without GPS. I'd love to hear more about the stories from your late-night shifts.

dialogue_content.original_text: One time, I had this passenger who was convinced the world was ending and insisted on going to their favorite diner for one last meal.
dialogue_content.speaker: Subject

dialogue_content.original_text: Oh, and I was saving up for a medallion back then, a real dream for any taxi driver.
dialogue_content.speaker: Subject
Interviewer
dialogue_content.text: It sounds like those late-night shifts were full of interesting characters and stories. How did saving for a medallion impact your time as a taxi driver?

dialogue_content.speaker: Subject
dialogue_content.original_text: Well, saving for a medallion was always in the back of my mind. Owning one was like owning a piece of the city, a key to the streets. I remember there were times I'd drive extra hours just to get closer to that goal.

dialogue_content.speaker: Interviewer
dialogue_content.text: So when did things change with your goal of getting a medallion?

dialogue_content.speaker: Subject
dialogue_content.original_text: Oh, well, that changed a bit later on. There was a time when the prices of medallions shot up. I remember feeling a bit disheartened. I remember there was a time I almost gave up chasing the medallion dream altogether.

dialogue_content.speaker: Interviewer
dialogue_content.text: It sounds like saving up for a medallion was quite a journey. Could you tell me about some of the challenges you faced along the way?

dialogue_content.original_text: There were always unexpected expenses, like repairs on the car.
dialogue_content.speaker: Subject

dialogue_content.original_text: But then, I'd get a good fare or a generous tip, and it would lift my spirits.
dialogue_content.speaker: Subject
Interviewer
dialogue_content.text: That must have been hard, working such long hours just to keep your dream alive. Can you tell me about a specific moment that tested your resolve?

dialogue_content.original_text: I remember one particular winter, the snow was relentless.
dialogue_content.speaker: Subject

dialogue_content.original_text: When we got there, the gentleman gave me the biggest tip I'd ever seen.
dialogue_content.speaker: Subject
Interviewer
dialogue_content.text: It must have felt rewarding when perseverance paid off like that. But I'm curious, what were some of the adjustments you had to make as the industry started to change?

dialogue_content.original_text: I remember when those yellow cabs started getting those fancy meters that printed out receipts.
dialogue_content.speaker: Subject

dialogue_content.original_text: You know, when those ride-sharing apps started popping up.
dialogue_content.speaker: Subject
Interviewer
dialogue_content.text: So as the industry was changing with the rise of ride-sharing apps, how did you feel about the impact on your work and your dream of owning a medallion?

dialogue_content.speaker: Subject
dialogue_content.original_text: Oh, well, it was a tough pill to swallow, to be honest. Suddenly, the medallion wasn't the golden ticket it once was. But then, you know, I realized that life doesn't always go the way you plan. I guess I learned to adapt, focus on the present, and find joy in the everyday rides.

dialogue_content.speaker: Interviewer
dialogue_content.text: That must have been really challenging, seeing such a big shift in the industry. How did you manage to stay resilient during that time?

dialogue_content.original_text: There was this one lady, a regular, who used to tell me about her garden.
dialogue_content.speaker: Subject
Interviewer
dialogue_content.text: I'd love to hear more about how those small joys kept you going during such turbulent times.

dialogue_content.original_text: You know, there was this one time I picked up a family heading to a picnic in Central Park.
dialogue_content.speaker: Subject
Interviewer
dialogue_content.text: Before we finish, Ahmed, could you share a final lesson or piece of wisdom that you'd like to pass on from your years behind the wheel?

dialogue_content.speaker: Subject
dialogue_content.original_text: Oh, that's a good question. You know, after all these years, I'd say it's important to embrace change. I learned that you can't always stick to your planned route, sometimes you have to take detours. Also, never underestimate the power of human connection. So, I guess my advice would be to stay open-minded, cherish the small moments, and always keep moving forward.
